description.narrative:
Diakonia har ansökt hos Sida om finansiering av 45 MSEK i syfte att genomföra "CSO monitoring Présimètre Programme" i Burkina Faso under perioden 2017-2019. Insatsen syftar till att konsolidera en demokratisk kultur i landet och institutionalisera medborgerlig övervakning av offentlig maktutövning genom användandet av ICT för att: 1) främja och försvara respekten för mänskliga rättigheter; 2) stärka demokratisk kultur, ansvarsutkrävande, politiskt deltagande särskilt för kvinnor och unga samt god samhällsstyrning; 3) övervaka och påverka offentligt beslutsfattande; 4) kräva ökad ekonomisk och social rättvisa; 5) ta frågor relaterade till miljö, vatten och sanitet i beaktande.
Den totala budgeten för insatsen uppgår till 66 MSEK, av vilka Sida finansierar 45 MSEK och övrig finansiering söks från EU, Schweiz och andra potentiella givare.

Diakonia has requested to Sida for funding of 45 million SEK to carry out the ""Program for strengthening political and economic accountability: public policies’ citizen monitoring and ICT www.presimètre.bf"" in Burkina Faso during the period 2016-2020.
The intervention aims at consolidating democratic culture and institutionalize citizen monitoring of public action through the use of ICT by. (1) promotioning, protecting and defencing human rights; (2) strengthening democratic culture, accountability, political participation of women and youth and good governance; (3) monitoring and influence public policies; (4) pleasing for economic and social justice, (5) taking into account issues related to the environment, water and sanitation. Diakonia will implement the intervention together with local civil society organisation.
The intervention’s total budget is 66 million SEK, and the remaining 21 million SEK is to be sought from other donors like EU and Switzerland with whom Diakonia has started a negociation. Approximately 27,4 million SEK of the intervention budget will be forwarded from Diakonia to twelve local organisations.

The overall objective of the program is to strengthen political and socio-economic accountability at national and local level by the monitoring of public policies for structural change from 2016 to 2020. The fifteen implementing partners will contribute to the five expected results in accordance with their field of competence. The five expected results are the following: 1. The democratic culture is reinforced by the continuous practice and the routinization of monitoring by citizens 2. Dialogue and Citizen Interpellation Frameworks including men and women enable adjustments to the actions of the government 3. ICTs enable real-time monitoring and strong involvement of youths and women in democratic governance 4. The Présimètre is a repository of political and socio-economic accountability 5. The technical and operational skills of Diakonia and partners are strengthened The intervention is based on a rights'-based approach and change strategy which corresponds to Diakonia's vision of the way in which the citizens' participation, non-discrimination, transparency, and accountability must be taken into account in the policies and strategies of development. A major amendment was agreed upon with Diakonia in March 2020, extending the activity period of the programme until December 31, 2020. As part of the amendment the results framework was updated somewhat, including results 1 and 2. In 2019, the Swiss Cooperation joined the donor group and with their funding an additional two partners joined the programme, focusing mainly of the participation of women and youth.

description.narrative: The results presented below are drawn from Diakonia's reporting from 2019 and from the first semester of 2020; as well as from a ROM (Results Oriented Monitoring) report commissioned by the European Union. The ROM report was submitted in March 2020 and shared with the Embassy of Sweden in September 2020. Overall the programme has delivered results in a satisfactorily manner at partner level, i.e. the fifteen implementing partners who are involved in the programme. The partners have managed to deliver despite of challenges in terms of the rapidly changing security context, the volatile socio-political context, specifically in regards to the many strikes in 2019 and the Covid 19 pandemic. The programme has managed to create spaces for dialogue between duty bearers and right holders at both local and national level, spaces which had been previously almost non existent, and thus creating a culture of accountability. The programme has managed this by using different tools (studies, opinion polls, citizen cafés, documentaries, etc) and by utilising the specific competencies of each partners. However the programme, and thus Diakonia, has not been able to create an overall programme dynamic to ensure that the programme is greater than the sum of its parts, i.e. the glue holding all of these activities together in a coherent whole has not been strong enough. Furthermore, the programme has been lacking in strengthening the participation of women and youth even if some improvements can be noted as of late. Please find some some examples of results below. 1. The democratic culture is reinforced by the continuous practice and the routinization of monitoring by citizens REN-LAC (Réseau national de Lutte anti-corruption) has through its annual publications on the state of corruption in Burkina Faso and through sensitisation sessions contributed to the increase of denunciations of corrupt practices, in 2019 379 complaints were registered (well over the goal of 300 complaints). Furthermore REN-LAC denounced several cases of corruption and was as a civil party in at least 5 cases which were brought to justice. CNPNZ (Centre National de Presse Norbert Zongo) published a memorandum on advocating for improved legislation in the area of freedom of press. Advocacy meetings resulted in commitments from two parliamentary groups and the National High Council for Communication to accompany CNPNZ in this issue. These advocacy efforts have continued in 2020. 2. Dialogue and Citizen Interpellation Frameworks including men and women enable adjustments to the actions of the government GERDDES (Groupe d’études et de recherche sur la démocratie et le développement économique et social) has organised dialogue meetings (cadre de dialogue et d'interpellation) at local levels to enable dialogue on public services in areas such as health, water and sanitation and education. These meetings resulted in the acquisition and repair of ambulances in some municipalities. More importantly they contributed to a culture of accountability and participation at municipal level. In 2019, Free Afrik Institute published two studies: "Terrorism and inter-community conflicts" and "Popular uprising: 5 years later where is Burkina Faso? ". The realization of the study on terrorism and the vast communication campaign around the security issue contributed to raising the awareness of the political authorities and the military hierarchy of the need to reflect in a concrete way on an effective strategy of fight against insecurity. Subsequently, the Free Afrik Institute was invited by the President of Burkina Faso to be a member of the commission which drafted the National Security Policy. The commission delivered its report to the President of Burkina Faso in January 2020. It is the very first official document serving as a reference in the fight against insecurity in Burkina Faso. 3. ICTs enable real-time monitoring and strong involvement of youths and women in democratic governance ABB (Associations des Blogueurs du Burkina) collaborated with REN-LAC in organising a training for blogers on anti-corruption which enabled a social media campaign against impunity and economic crimes. Diakonia has continued to broadcast the "Dialogue Citoyen" on the national tv channel RTB. In 2019 11 of those shows were broadcast and several ministers participated and were questioned on achievements within their respective sectors, thus contributing to a culture of accountability. The issue of the digital tools being used by mainly a male urban elite remains. 4. The Présimètre is a repository of political and socio-economic accountability CODEL (Convention des Organisations de la société civile pour l’Observation Domestique des Elections) undertook a certain number of activities in anticipation of the 2020 presidential and legislative elections. CODEL remains a key actor in the electoral process. 5. The technical and operational skills of Diakonia and partners are strengthened In 2019, partners were strengthened in the area of conflict sensitivity and gender mainstreaming through trainings. The different partners have also increasingly been able to work together to create synergy effects. Certain unexpected results should be noted: - Negative unexpected results - the perception that the digital tools used by the programme are elitist (i.e. only available to an urban male elite), likewise that the research studies published within the framework of the programme are only made available in a small elite group. - Positive unexpected results - the opportunity for one of the implementing partners to provide input to the national security policy (see above).
